title: The Army says it has picked who will build the Patriot radar replacement, but it isn’t saying who the winner is
text:
The US Army has selected a winner to build the Lower Tier Air and Missile Defense Sensor (LTAMDS), Army officials revealed at AUSA 2019 in Washington, DC.

The LTAMDS will be a radar replacement for the Raytheon-built Patriot air-and-missile defense system radars that have been in service for decades.

Raytheon, Northrop Grumman, and a Lockheed Martin-Elta Systems team have been competing for this contract.

The Army has yet to announce a winner because negotiations with the company are ongoing.

The US Army has decided on a vendor for its Patriot radar replacement, the Lower Tier Air and Missile Defense Sensor (LTAMDS), but it is still in the process of hammering out a deal with the winning company, which the Army has not yet announced.

The LATMDS is the Army's next-generation missile-defense radar and a replacement for the Patriot systems that first entered service in the 1980s.

Brig. Gen. Brian Gibson, head of the Army's Air and Missile Defense Cross-Functional Team, gave an update on the program Tuesday at the Association of the US Army in Washington, DC, revealing that a winner had been selected but that the Army is "still actively negotiating."

An announcement is expected in the coming weeks.

Raytheon’s LTAMDS solution displayed on the floor at AUSA 2019. Ryan Pickrell/Business Insider

The Army was initially expected to select from among three major players — a Lockheed Martin-Elta Systems team, Raytheon, and Northrop Grumman — before the end of fiscal year 2019, which was September 30, to build a new, more capable air-and-missile defense platform to replace the Raytheon-built Patriot system that has served for decades, but that didn't happen.

The decision follows a "sense off" at White Sands Missile Range in New Mexico earlier this year that featured live air tracks and target injections, as well as the presentation of radar configuration models, Breaking Defense reported in August.

The company the Army selects will build six prototypes by 2022, with follow-on orders if the end result meets the Army's needs for current and future warfare.

The LTAMDS is a key priority for Army Futures Command's Air and Missile Defense Cross-Functional Team, which is the fifth-highest priority among the eight cross-functional team.
description: The Army has finally made a decision, but it is "still actively negotiating" with the yet-to-be-announced winner.
